NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting both and far? How many of these were bachelor's houses?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? What time of the day did you go—in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Usually in afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "make pollack" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "meeses" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "meese" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in houses? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times—every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
SASKATCHEWAN HISTORY QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 5

Flower Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go? — in the morning and noon the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Usually in afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?

(That is, was the turn to make pollock used, or was some other expression commonly used?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, whilst drives or dances in homes?

Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turns from one home to another at definite times — every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school questionaire, etc.)

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of?
Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? If so, where?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if the school house was used for district gatherings, did you continue to use the school house for other functions, or were you forced to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?))

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in houses, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings?

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house. For community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, plant sale, etc.)

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? How large was it?

What material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

For what purpose did it take the place of home or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you able enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Has there been playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at "formality," or "sophistic," do you remember in small towns, such as Grove Hill? (Note when calling, calling cards, whether treated ceremonially in parties, etc.)

13. Was the chivalry known in your community?

Describe what you remember about chivalry, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?
